Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Scamp \Scamp\ (sk[a^]mp), n. [OF. escamper to run away, to make one's escape. Originally, one who runs away, a fugitive, a vagabond. See {Scamper}.] A rascal; a swindler; a rogue. --De Quincey. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Scamp \Scamp\, v. t. [Cf. {Scamp},n., or {Scant}, a., and {Skimp}.] To perform in a hasty, neglectful, or imperfect manner; to do superficially. [Colloq.] [1913 Webster]
A workman is said to scamp his work when he does it in a superficial, dishonest manner. --Wedgwood. [1913 Webster]
Much of the scamping and dawdling complained of is that of men in establishments of good repute. --T. Hughes. [1913 Webster]
scamp n : one who is playfully mischievous [syn: {imp}, {monkey}, {rascal}, {rapscallion}, {scalawag}, {scallywag}] v : perform hastily and carelessly
